intro: Ocimum fimbriatum var. microphyllum, commonly known as the dwarf holy basil, is a variant of the holy basil plant native to tropical regions of Africa and southern Asia. It is characterized by its small, ovate leaves and purple or white flowers, which bloom in terminal clusters. The plant typically grows to a height of around 30–60 cm, making it a compact and ornamental species. It thrives in warm, humid climates and is often cultivated for its aromatic foliage and medicinal properties. The leaves are used in traditional medicine and cooking, similar to other members of the Ocimum genus.
